title: Will Russians conduct airstrikes in Syria before 1 May 2016?
preds: Looks like a bunch of us will get 0 for our Brier scores. This was one of those egg on the way to the floor predictions.

Now confirmed by Russia
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/30/russia-launches-first-airstrikes-against-targets-in-syria-says-us
"A spokesman for Russia’s defence ministry confirmed Russia had hit military and communication equipment “belonging to terrorists” in the country on Wednesday afternoon."

It's all over, but the shouting:
MOSCOW — Russian warplanes launched airstrikes in Syria on Wednesday, a U.S. official said, after Russia’s parliament granted President Vladi­mir Putin authorization to use military force in the multi-layered conflict.
They have officially launched air strikes according to news reports.
Assets were deployed and ready to use. Iraq-Iran-Syria-Russia intelligence sharing deal enables it further.
Russia has been announced to be "ready".

Upping to 100%. Apart from legal measures, rhetoric from various Russian officials, and the statement by Sergei Ivanov (Minister of Foreign Affairs) that Russia's decision is in response to a direct request from Assad appear to make this all but certain.

Confirmed, I guess
http://edition.cnn.com/2015/09/30/politics/russia-syria-airstrikes-isis/index.html/
"Russia has conducted its first airstrike in Syria, near the city of Homs, a senior U.S. official told CNN Wednesday ."

The Duma have provided Russian-style legitimacy for this operation, and bombing of somebody will start in the next couple of days. It'll be interesting to see who gets bombed after the initial targeting of IS operations.  Putin is as likely as not to go all Turkish and start bombing people he disapproves of who aren't IS, but somebody is getting bombed quite soon.
Russia fulfilled all legal necessaries to support the legitimate power in Syria. Only air support will be conducted at this time.

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/11900853/Putin-request-for-use-of-Russian-troops-in-Syria-approved-live.html
Unconfirmed claims of Russian airstrikes on Homs province.
....and I've just seen the Duma vote
Putin given approval to use troops in Syria. Upping my forecast.
reports from US officials today that Russia will be launching imminently and not against IS targets.  Possibility that it's US scare mongering still but seems more likely to be an answer soon.

The quantity and type of Russian aircraft, including attack helicopters, already seen in Syria as of September 2015 tell me that these systems are far more than what is needed to "force protection" purposes, as was stated as their purposes by Russian senior government officials.

The Russian Duma today voted unanimously to permit Russian military action in Syria. This is as clear and overwhelming a green light as can be imagined, compared with the behind-the-scenes suggestions that have been evident hitherto.
Update due to Russian parliament approval of military action and the likelihood of Assad regime giving permission for air strikes.
Putin just got duma authorization for military action in Syria. I imagine it's coming soon - if not already happening.

Russian parliament unanimously approves use of troops in Syria
http://www.rt.com/news/317013-parliament-authorization-troops-abroad/
It is however more likely that more "little green men" will start appearing as opposed to marked Russian aircraft.
It looks like Russia is setting up a no-fly zone over both Syria and the eastern Meditarranean now.
No brainer, given the latest satellite images from NYT.
Assuming "Russians" in this question means official Russian military personnel flying red star-marked planes.
Russians are building up now to support to do so.  I would expect this to occur before YE

France carries out airstrikes against IS in Syria
http://www.dw.com/en/france-carries-out-airstrikes-against-is-in-syria/a-18744167

Increase due to the movement of Russian air assets into Al Assad airfield reported in janes. http://www.janes.com/article/54732/russia-to-defend-core-syrian-government-areas?utm_campaign=PC6110_E15%20DF%20NL%20Security%2009_29_15&utm_medium=email&utm_source=Eloqua

Mr. Putin intends to "... cooperate with the Syrian government and its armed forces, who are valiantly fighting terrorism face-to-face,” whatever that means for Mr. Putin/Russia, considering that Russia and Syria are longtime allies, with deeply interwoven personal and military connections, their intention in the end are mainly to support Assad.
Another factor is the weak Russian economy.
So airstrikes, yes, to what use/extent will shall see.

Putin may look like a mad man, but he is very strategic and systematic. He does not  put his resources where he does not intend to utilize them. He has a plan to overshadow the US, and start nominal airstrikes to shore up Assad and solidify Russian position in Syria at some point. Most likely within the next six months.
news is out that they are ready to start
Russia is open about its intention to help Assad.

BBC:  "Syria conflict: Russia considers joining anti-IS air strikes":http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-34387433
After the face-to-face between Vladdy and Obama, Vladdy said Russia would conduct air strikes only if they were approved by the United Nations, while also ruling out Russian troops taking part in a ground operation in Syria.

With Russia moving increasing arms towards Syria it is highly likely that they will use air strikes against the country. As NATO nations help the rebel groups they will help the government to reduce the risk of NATO influence close to its traditional area of influence.  It will also be an opportunity for him to play the hero and fight against ISIS which he can use in rhetoric against the NATO nations and for publicity back home. With the strong relationship, both politically and militarily, it is unlikely Russia would risk Syria and her interests being taken by ISIS or a group affiliated with NATO.
Yes, I think they will within the week.

Reports are that they will do so once Assad gives his approval.  If this is being said publicly then the agreement is most likely mostly made.
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/vladimir-putin/11898214/Vladimir-Putin-Russia-will-join-coalition-air-strikes-against-Isil-if-it-is-approved-by-Assad.html
Russia announced on September 29 that they were considering joining the air strikes in Syria.

Russia is determined to stop ISIS, since it is a direct threat to its allies borders.  Also it wants to fight the ca. 1500 ISIS fighters who where recruited from Russian and former USSR states rather in Syria than having them return to their respective home countries for potential terror attacks. ISIS can be successfully fought only by ground forces, which Russia is not planning to sent as for now. Therefore, the Russian air force is in place in Syria for two reasons: At first it will block NATO from playing a double game, announcing to bomb ISIS, but in deed destroying Syrian's army assets, similar as it happened in Libya. Secondary, it will support the Syrian and Kurdish forces, which are the only forces fighting ISIS on the ground as for now. After meeting with Obama yesterday, who accepted the necessity to cooperate with the only real ground force in place, which is fighting ISIS - namely the regular Syrian army, it became clear that USA and Russia will coordinate their effort in the air to avoid friendly fire. Russia will use its air force only based on international law, in opposition to NATO. That means, that it will be an approval by UN SC, or a direct request by Assad, which was not publicly announced as for now. My prognosis I have adjusted to the new developments of Obama retracting from his loudly pronounced position to not to cooperate with Assad. It seems that US's policy to use yet another terror organization to seed chaos has worked only to a limited degree - it did destabilize smaller players like Libya, Syria Iraq, but the main geopolitical target Russia is well prepared and much too strong to be dealt with in this manner. China has sent its air carrier to Syria demonstrating its support for Russia. As predicted, the one who wants every thing will become nothing. US administration made strategic mistakes and will see its empire crumbling - which is for its own people actually a good thing - but this is another topic.
Russian fighters and attack helicopters already in Syria.  Costs too much to get that equipment into a foreign theater and not use it.
a probable agreement with Us,Iran and F and GB
yes, but not necessarily as part of the coalition

Now that they've shown their cards, to not follow through would indicate weakness - I don't think that is acceptable. Also, rather than supplying weapons or choosing covert means (cyber), this action indicates their willingness to placate the West, a quid pro quo, in return for a reduction in sanctions. Such an action would make Russia a kind of Western proxy, or won't it? I'm not sure how comfortable Putin is with that idea. 
However the possibility of such an action opening up a veritable Pandora's box for Russia is forcing me to tone down my estimate to 70%.

I requested a clarification from the GJP team about whether this included strikes against ISIS and the response was yes. Added to that Putin's comments at the UNGA yesterday, I would say the chances of a Russian strike in Syria against ISIS are very likely even if they are cosmetic.

Going up on the NYT coverage of Putin / Obama meeting.  They're playing up conflict, but it actually seems to me like the 2 parties are on the same page.  It's rhetoric getting in the way, not interest.

Reading between the lines, from the news coming during the U.N. meetings, the U.S. appears to be giving Russia a nod to go ahead and hit ISIS in Syria. Raising this for now, but may bring it back down if Russia seems to be doing something other than air-strikes.

I very much dount it, though some of you are certain of it. Airsrikes attract alot of attention. They may offer support or may fly under the Syrian flag but flying under Russian flag and dropping bombs prob wont happen. Also Russia does not have the accuracy US bombs have, we take that for granted. IF Russia conducts airstrikes expect massive civilian casualties. Not that Syria is against civilian deaths but Assad has nothing to lose, Russia does.

This seems a very easy one with this time frame.  Their initial force concentration is at an airport.  Naturally that makes supply easier, but its difficult for me to believe they will not use it as a base of operations to conduct air strikes.  And isn't ISIL in a part of Syria?  The whole idea of resisting ISIL is the justification Putin is giving for this action.

Putin is helping Assad and himself. Let's not fool ourselves. His positioning of military forces into Syria is a show of strength and his willingness to take on tough challenges in a fragmented region. He will use his power if he needs too. He has shown that several times already. He is the "American Cowboy" riding in, granted it's for the wrong side.

Syrian "Peace Talks" announced; planned for October.
http://theworldweekly.com/newswire/reader/russia-seizes-the-initiative-on-syria-expecting-peace-talks-in-october-as-world-leaders-gather-at-the-un-general-assembly/4993
ISIS growing in strength and Putin is 96% committed to keeping Assad in power.

Yes. Russia is taking the lead in supporting Syria (among western countries). The French have already begun airstrikes. I believe it is a matter of time before there is a recognised coalition of western nations who conduct airstrikes in Syria, with Russia being among them.
Very unlikely that there will be an open intervention. Rus tries to work a "hybrid" operation just like in Ukr most recently.

Increasing likelihood  - apparently Chinese are coming too, with their Marines & planes:   So something likely to happen before May 2016.    Not sure they need all that firepower for ISIS, but maybe Russia & China having more of a problem with jihadists than we've heard?    Or ?

While I definitely think that this is probable, I'm a bit more hestitatnt to go towards near-certainty. While Russia has states their commitment to bolstering Asad and hurting ISIS, it's unclear to me right now what measures they will end up taking.

The Russians have sent the appropriate aircraft and are entering an environment where other countries have already done this as well.  There is no immediate downside for the Russians in doing this, both to demonstrate resolve against ISIS and to shore up their own regime in Assad. They need to gather intelligence and plan the missions, but no reason that cannot occur before 1 May.
Everything Russia is up to is moving in that direction, and Putin seems to have little problem dropping bombs.

It may enable Putin to show that Mother Russia is the only country with the strength to defeat ISIS by working with Syria/Iran/Iraq and if he can in some way tie this war to the Muslim extremists in his satellite countries, he will be able to expand the battle and promote nationalism.
Seems especially likely with the new information sharing accord reached this morning.
The strike planes are there already; countries rarely set up weapon systems that they don't intend on using - especially when strikes are already being conducted by other countries.

Seems likely given this from Putin:
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/24/us-mideast-crisis-russia-airstrikes-idUSKCN0RO01320150924

Yes.  While personally, Putin likely couldn't care less about whether Assad stays or goes, the opportunity to be the 'king-maker' in Middle Eastern politics and at the same time displacing the US as the regional power broker is a unique, generational opportunity that he will not allow to pass.  Power and absolute power is Putin's oxygen.

If Putin has not already done so, he will. There is no downside for him, only for the casualties, and he needs to strut on the world stage. It may even get him a seat at an'y future negotiations on settling  Assads future. Warren
It is an opportunity for Putin to flex his might. Too tempting to pass up.

Russia did not move a regiment of fighters on a whim.  They are there for a purpose.  Putin will save his Arab client.  Any protests and VVP will point to already existing anti-ISIL airstrikes by others.
Too much political pressure and nothing to gain.

1:  Apparently the Syrians are using Russian planes for strikes, so ? no need for Russian pilots to be involved; claims Russia there to "support' the only legitimate army (Syrian Army.)    
2:  Moscow news (& perhaps military) not enthusiastic about Russian involvement in Syrian battle. 
3:  Previous Russian stance was west's military involvement in Middle East a bad idea. A c0mplete turnaround might be difficult to justify in Moscow
Perhaps wants to support Assad as well as create/expand a "Mediterranean"  Russian base and a safe area for Alawites.  
Not sure what else yet but if Russians start airstrikes with all US, French and others flying over Syria it is a potential for even more problems.
They have boots on the ground, plans, and all the infrastructure.  Not investing this much money without a plan to implement.  They are aware that their is no country who will stop them.
You usually don't put warplanes in a theatre and not use them.

The Russian buildup will continue, and Putin (as well as many in the West and the region) will see various national interests served by greater Russian involvement, the least risky for Putin will be air strikes.
....highly likely.......a military commitment of the current magnitude won't go unused
Planes in place. Putin's bullying strategy.
Russia will attack and they will deny it.

Russia is no stranger to lending planes and pilots to proxy conflicts (i.e. the Korean war). They seem to have thrown their lot in with Assad, and do not want to be seen as being less tough on IS than the western coalition currently conducting airstrikes.

Russia has always supported Assad, but that support now seems to be inadequate to stanch the bleeding. Assad is loosing city after city to ISIS - to avoid looking like a loser who bet on the wrong horse - which incidentally, Putin has done a lot of in the Middle East, Putin simply has to put more on the scale to maintain the same equilibrium.
They will provide support/intelligence, but will not conduct airstrikes under their own flag i.e. Ukraine.
The have not snuck in those planes for fun!
Following the herd on this one.
Now that the French have started bombing stuff, Putin can start doing so without using the Ukraine Figleaf.  Probably start within the next week, so I am likely too low on this.
The airplanes are not there for a show of force.  They will be used.
Russia will do what it takes to prop up Assad - air strikes will be a way to do this against ISIS.

They did not move so many airplanes, military etc. for nothing. In addition Russians are not shy on the question of engaging military on the ground and therefore let's not speak about conducting military airstrikes. By May 2016 seems a reasonable time to coordinate/inform others on the field, identify targets and act.
Putin will ensure his guy stays
Seems likely given the Russian military buildup in Syria and Putin's demonstrated desire to challenge U.S. power in the region and continue supporting Assad.
Military activities in the region are underway already.
This is a prediction that there may be a 20% chance that there will be a ceasefire and hence no need for a Russian airstike.

"Unconfirmed reports from Syrian government and pro-rebel sources are already indicating that Russian airstrikes may have commenced in support of the push to relieve loyalist forces at Aleppo's Kweiris air base."
https://www.stratfor.com/analysis/analytic-guidance-what-us-russia-talks-syria-portend

Russia wants to assert its claim that it is an interested party in the Syrian crisis. And, unlike the US-led coalition, as an ally of the Syrian government, Russia thinks that she has the right (and an obligation?) to help Syria against the terrorists. She would want to show that they are very much a part of the solution, and would want  to make that solution a desirable outcome for themselves. When we zoom out, the situation in Ukraine is a possible component to be considered in this question. A better negotiating position for both these issues would warrant, at least partial, air strikes in Syria.
The CIA said it was GOING TO HAPPEN-----http://newswire.net/newsroom/news/00090548-cia-russia-is-ready-to-attack-targets-in-syria.html
They already have. It was in the WSJ last week.
It may be drone based, but higher potential with munitions provided and technology complexities

So , the question is, can the US stomach Putin's proposal?
http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN0RO01320150924
No.  They are not going to raise their level of involvement beyond their current intervention.

Several factors portend a dangerous escalation and higher likelihood of conflict between Russia, it allies Iran, Iraq (Shite components), Hezbollah and locally allied insurgents such as the AQ affiliate Al Nusra Front, AND, the Washington coalition, Nato and its western allies and insurgents it supports on the ground.  Russian participation in military operations, the deepening role of Russia in Syria, and the role of Iran, Iraq, Lebanon and Hezbollah are of grave concern by Washington and its allies and the Nato alliance.  A stark policy conflict between Russia and the US over the role of Assad in a potentially stable Syria in the future increases conflict potential and could result in greater loss of life & battle deaths, increased refugee flows, and conflict with the anti-IS coalition of insurgents on the ground.
Based on recent news reports, the probability of this occurring appears to be high.
Seems very likely since Russia wants to increase its influence in the region as well as prevent the spread of Isis into Russian territories.

The Russians will make an air strike in Syria before Christmas 2015. They are not there to defend a fellow dictator but upstage the US and show they can act on the international stage. VP longs for the Cold War.

http://sputniknews.com/politics/20150924/1027446942/russia-air-force-syria-kremlin.html
The political implications seem to be around who actually flies the planes and it seems more and more likely that Russia is pushing the US to lead it but it feels unlikely they will do so - if not I'm not sure Russia is going to want to take that political step beyond supplying planes to conducting the airstrikes themselves without international support.  7 months is a long time though.
My sense is that the West would welcome it at this point. It doesn't even have to be much, just a show of force.
Obama and Merkel are going to meet Putin next week. Obama wants to finish Syria quickly. Europe is not interested in a flood of immigrants. They need to solve the question with Putin first.
they have moved warplanes in. so they will probably use them.
The Russians have all they need in place.  If they are to support the Assad regime, they must act as soon as possible, probably within days.
The term airstrike is undefined and multiple are required. There are certainly plenty of offensive aircraft in the theater now. Do helo attacks count even it's only the insertion of ground troops?
Putin is too smart to do so; he is playing mind game.
The jets are not there for a show of force.  Outside of the US and Europe a show of force involves blowing stuff up.
I don't think they sent all the expensive equipment to Syria for show. They will certainly use the Mi-24's and they will probably use the aircraft.

They are unlikely to have spent the scarce funds needed to engage in this buildup without an intent to use the force.
By signaling that they intend to intervene, it would cost them a loss of face if they then chose not to use the forces deployed.
Conducting airstrikes helps them support the Assad regime and maintain Syria as a client state; failing to strike increases the chance they will be embarrassed by losing a client state. Airstrikes allow them to claim that if you align with them you get action, while if you align with the US you get abandoned.  The potential to embarrass the US as a motivation for airstrikes should not be underestimated. There is little to dissuade them from using airstrikes. If they weren't deterred from invading Crimea and the Ukraine by international opinion, they won't be deterred by public opinion here where they may well claim they are just helping stop ISIS and other terrorists (regardless of whether they are hitting non-terrorist targets as well).

How will anyone prove independently that Russia did conduct an airstrike?  Russia can easily maintain deniability.  I'm not sure how this question will be answered and that's as important as what the Russians do?

Overall, I think airstrikes in Syria are unlikely because I believe the United States will warn Russia about future economic sanctions that the international community will place on Russia. Although Putin attempts to appeal to the nationalistic/Russian axis of power ideology, I believe that ultimately he understands the economic connection Russia must maintain with the international community.

Syria plays a reasonable role in V. Putinâ€™s plan of reshaping balance of forces in the world. Although, Putin says Russia is preparing for unilateral air strikes against Islamic State in Syria if the United States rejects his proposal to join forces, current military presence of Russia in Syria indicates that airstrikes will happen anyway.

While a major reason for the buildup may be geopolitical and designed to pressure the US. However, they certainly would like to support Assad. There would be minimal if any downside to directly attacking ISIS.

Russia wants to prop up Assad regime & Iran.  Supporting Assad w/ military equipment now, and will likely use own force in coordinated airstrikes similar to the what the U.S, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Turkey etc. have been doing

Primary reason is for Vladimir Putin to cement his foothold in the Middle East as an alternative to the listless US presence.  It will be done in 2016 if for no other reason than to ensure there are no real consequences for his actions before a new US President is in office.  The deadline established per the question is the only reason I have it at 75%.  If we used by the end of 2016, I would have it at 99%
The Russians have waited long time for this ....they are ready

Given the recent movements of equipment to conduct airstrikes to Syria, likelyhood of some coordianation of effort between US and Russia, Putin and Obama talking, Russia desire to maintain Assad as Syrian leader, the probability of Russian airstrikes seems quite high within this time period.
Given the number of outside countries already launching airstrikes, specific capacity increases, and increased Russian presence, strikes seem likely to me.

And herein lies the rub:  attribution.  According to Reuters, Syrian pilots are at the controls (http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/24/us-mideast-crisis-syria-jets-idUSKCN0RO15V20150924).  How do you prove otherwise?  Last year, in Ukraine, there was never anything definitive that Russian troops were involved in the fighting.  There were reports, funerals, and eventually the question resolved to "yes", but it will be much harder with planes to assign responsibility.  If you label a mission as "covert" to your own personnel, doesn't that make it more prestigious?
Against ISIL, yes, I think so.
If only for Putin to show how much of a man he is.
Russia has a large number of Russian citizens joining ISIS in Syria. They want to stabilize the government of syria. They don't see the rebels as a viable alternative

Player number one in Russia, with Syria and U.S. far less significant players as to the outcome of the question. 
Russia aims to throw its weight around in Syria and support Bashar.
They are highly motivated in pursuit of that goal, as evidenced by the recent transfer of two dozen airplanes. 
All signs point to Russia eventually conducting airstrikes.  With a six-month horizon on this question, I'd place my bets on a positive outcome.

Russia has transparently stated that they plan to conduct airstrikes against IS very soon, if the situation vis-a-vis the US does not change. They already have equipment in place and will likely have personnel in place very soon, based on recent reports.
Sold!  Two French built Mistrals going to Egypt, possibly financed by Saudi Arabia.  Russian military equipment to remain onboard. Egypt/Russian cooperation apparent in the Med.

Russia would prefer to supply Syria to defend itself _and_ Russian interests in Syria.  (Most importantly, Russian access to the naval base at Tartus.)  However, Russia has military assets in place to defend its supply of Syria, namely significant air assets.  I rate airstrikes highly for the following reasons:
USA & Russia have secret deal to end war in Syria.Probably involving some Russian airstrikes similar to USA.
or this is a great, big, gigantic bluff for the satellites.  Remember a certain pipeline last season?  They had the capacity on the barges booked.  They had the staging areas full.
The only way for Russia to actively support Assad is a direct intervention with airstrikes..
This seems all but certain.  Just for some more news:
Russia ha splanes in place to prevent fall of Assad. Airpower will be essential for this purpose.

What this comes down to is whether any credible reports surface of SU-25 or SU-30 attack aircraft being used. Some Syrian pilots have flown SU-24 aircraft that have long been owned by Syria. However, the appearance of SU-25s and SU-30s is new. If used, the pilots would be Russian over the next several months until Syrian pilots could complete training.

"Russian marines join Hizballah in first Syrian battle"
"For the first time in 41 years ...  Russian troops are fighting alongside Syrian forces."
http://www.debka.com/article/24902/Russian-marines-join-Hizballah-in-first-Syrian-battle-%E2%80%93-a-danger-signal-for-US-Israel

More politicking or a genuine expectancy that strikes will be conducted regardless of international support?
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/24/us-mideast-crisis-russia-airstrikes-idUSKCN0RO01320150924

There's a good chance this question will close today, if Kenneth Beck's report of a Reuters story is correct. The only question is whose pilots were in the cockpits. This could end up like last season's Russians in Ukraine question, where the scorers waited until the mainstream media were all insisting that the "little green men" coming home to Russia in coffins were not vacationing soldiers who had met unfortunate mishaps, but actually were operational, under military control.
That's why they sent the strike planes.

Before I saw this article http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-23/putin-said-to-plan-islamic-state-strikes-with-or-without-u-s-   , I wasn't entirely sure that Russia would actually conduct airstrikes. I thought it could all just be posturing, considering how Putin likes to show Russians how strong and powerful Russia/Putin is, which might still be the case. This article https://csis.org/publication/russia-syria-hybrid-political-warfare  does argue this point and is of the opinion that Russia is in a stronger position if it doesn't conduct airstrikes and instead uses the potential abilities of the airbase as a negotiation tool with Western countries in order to keep Assad in power.

It is very possible, because Russia moved some airplanes to Damascus:
http://lenta.ru/news/2015/09/01/syria/
The planes are there, so it makes sense to use them at some point. May 1 is 6 months away, so I think the odds of some air-strikes are high.
These numbers of fighters aren't there for shits and giggles...

If the Russians send in armed services, as a token gesture or more, expect a fight.  Without a reason for being somewhere in that area and having no guidance, they may end up like the US Marines in Beirut when the Reagan administration had no strategic idea as to why they were there and when Hezbollah blew the Marines up, the Reagan administration called for a retreat. It was then the terrorists knew the administration had no tolerance for spilling blood and it renewed the terrorist’s efforts in the area.  The rest is the historic present.

Russia expanding - building out two more bases:  http://www.wsj.com/articles/russia-expands-military-its-presence-in-syria-satellite-photos-show-1442937150?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=New%20Campaign&utm_term=%2ASituation%20Report

Open source weapons watching Oryx blog:  http://spioenkop.blogspot.com/2015/09/further-russian-air-force.html?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=New+Campaign&utm_term=*Situation+Report&m=1

According to Bloomberg and the BBC, Russia has established a forward airbase at Latakia and moved in 12 bombers, 12 ground attack aircraft, 4 multi-role fighter aircraft, two types of drones, and 20 helicopters. I don't think Russia would have done this as a posturing move because there are no negotiations underway in which posturing would serve a purpose. Russia apparently envisions two futures, one where they carry out airstrikes in coordination with the US, the other in which they carry them out without the US, either of which would cause this question to resolve as Yes. I am reserving 10% odds in case there is a diplomatic stalemate that prevents Russia from moving forward before 1 May 2016, or another unexpected event that changes Russia's plans.
No question. I will revisit with more detail.  Here is the detail this morning:
"Sources" in the Kremlin are saying that Putin is asking for joint US-Russian airstrikes and troops are moving into Syria.  This sounds like pretty serious action from Russia.
With the current rapid build up and arrival of combat aircraft, it seems likely this will resolve in the next few weeks.
Putin is working hard to win the hearts and minds of the Muslim world -- part of his Syria strategy?

There are Russian planes currently in Syria. It seems quite feasible that in the next 8 months there will be a Russian air strike. I hope reality proves me wrong since the consequences would be catastrophic.
They are opening more bases.  Then they can establish air strikes.

Putin wants to be taken seriously on the world stage, and more to the point, wants Russian citizens to belive he is taken seriosuly on the world stage. By becoming a tangible military force in Syria Putin ensures that Russia has a vocal say in eventual peace negotiations.
Yes, will likely assist in the reclaiming key areas under ISIL control in Syria

This does seem very likely, given the Russian jets being sent to Syria.  I still think it is less than a certainty; Syria could use the jets with their own pilots, which would not count as Russia conducting airstrikes.

It is a stage that Russia can make a play on. He needs to get his population accustomed to a war stance before he can enter into any serious conflicts with any nation that is perceived as a threat to their stability.  The call of war is growing louder.

There's no real downside for Russia in this. They are airstrikes, not boots on the ground. Reputation has already been put at stake. It strengthens Russia's relationship with Assad, the probably victor, and with other ISIS enemies such as Iran with whom Russia shares many interests.

Long time frame.  Consider the targets:
   1) IS - no issues, supported by US, Syria, Russia, or Iran.
   2) US backed Anti-Assad rebels, not supported by US.
   2) Other Anti-Assad Groups, not supported by the US.
Russia will likely start with an IS strike, but after that there are issues.  Russia will likely defend the existng Assad controlled Syrian borders from attacks by all forces, but, will Russia extend the attacks at some point to retake other portions of Syria?, those strikes may target US backed rebel groups.

It's an interesting question but given the worsening nature of Assad's position the Russian's may be wary of getting directly involved in bombing groups of people if they want to become a power broker with the competing factions inside Syria.  While there seems to be little doubt that it's supplying arms and advisors to Assad's forces (http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/22/syria-confirms-receipt-russian-jets-isis) I don't think the move from there to actually conducting the airstrikes themselves is as clear cut as some people seem to think, though still more likely than not.

With military advisers and personnel on the ground in the area, and reports of drone flights spotting target in the region it appears as though Russia is on a fast course for conducting military operations in the region.  Russia's engagement appears to be one of providing air support and military assistance to Assad.  Russia's main purpose in the region still seems to be to negotiate a deal between Syria (Assad) and the rebel factions; however, with the recent additional build up of military on the ground and air fighters I do believe there will be airstrikes in the near future.

Long term, Syria is useful to Russia several different ways: it provides air and sea bases on the Med; it provides a border front facing US forces in Iraq; it is a wedge helping to isolate Turkey; it provides about half the pipeline run between the Med and the Caspian gas and oil fields.
